questions.text: Which of the following is not a typical deformity seen in congenital talipes equinovarus?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Forefoot pronation Forefoot pronation is not seen in CTEV , but forefoot supination is seen . Deformities are seen in CTEV Cavus : High-arched foot Inversion : Occurs at Sub talar joint (Talocalcaneal joint) Adduction : Occurs at the forefoot, mainly involved is the talonavicular joint Varus : Occurs at calcaneum

Highyeild:

Congenital talipes equinovarus (clubfoot) is a deformity of the foot with an incidence of 1 in 250–1000. It is more common in males and is often bilateral. There may be associated musculoskeletal anomalies. A number of deformities are seen: forefoot adduction (tibialis posterior), forefoot supination (tibialis anterior), midfoot cavus (intrinsics, flexor hallucis longus, flexor digitorum longus), hindfoot varus (Achilles tendon, tibialis posterior) and hindfoot equinus (Achilles tendon).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A, C and D: Typical deformity seen in CTEV.

questions.text: The sequence of correction in CTEV is which?
questions.correct_answer: A. Cavus, adduction, varus and equinus
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cavus, adduction, varus and equinus Sequence of correction in CTEV Ponseti casting is ( CAVE ): cavus, adductus, varus, equinus.

Highyeild:

In CTEV, the ankle, subtalar, and midtarsal joints are involved in deformity formation. The neck of the talus points downwards and deviated medially. The body is rotated slightly outwards in relation to both the calcaneum and ankle mortise. A tight calcaneofibular ligament keeps the calcaneum and fibula very close and causes an equinus and varus deformity . The entire forefoot and the navicular are shifted medially and rotated into supination creating a varus deformity. The skin and soft tissues of the calf (Posteriorly: Tendoachilles, Capsule of the ankle joint, subtalar joint) and the medial side of the foo t (Tibialis posterior, Flexor digitorum longus and flexor hallucis longus, talonavicular ligament, spring ligament, and deltoid ligament) are underdeveloped and remain short.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options B, C & D. Sequence of correction in CTEV Ponseti casting is (CAVE): c avus, adductus, varus, equinus

questions.text: Pes cavus is most commonly associated with which disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Charcot Marie tooth disease Pes cavus is most commonly associated with Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease, it is a defect in the gene responsible for peripheral myelin protein 22 (PMP22).

Highyeild:

Charcot Marie Tooth Disease Cavus deformity of the foot (elevated longitudinal arch) with calcaneus or varus hindfoot Up to 67% of cases are due to n eurologic disorder Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease (most common): defect in the gene responsible for peripheral myelin protein 22 (PMP22 ) Also polio, cerebral palsy, Friedreich ataxia, myelomeningocele, and spinal cord injury, tumor, or abnormality

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Arthrogryposis multiplex congenita is a non-development of muscles causing Sporadic multiple contracture syndrome . Foot deformities in AMC include Vertical talus and equinovarus deformities. Option: C. Osgood schlatter disease is osteochondritis of the Tibial tuberosity. Option: D. Friedrich ataxia is an inherited disorder that leads to spinocerebellar degeneration and presents with cavovarus foot deformity.

questions.text: Gene defect in the following case is due to which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

FGFR3 Achondroplasia is the most common form of disproportionate short-limbed dwarfism. Autosomal dominant condition ; 80% of cases caused by a spontaneous mutation in the fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 (FGFR3) This leads to a gain-of-function mutation or uncontrolled activation

Highyeild:

ACHONDROPLASIA ● MC form of dwarfism ● AD disorder ● Pathophysiology: Failure of enchondra lossification (Bones remain short) (Intramembranous and Periosteal ossification is normal) ● Clinical features: ○ Short stature → IU life: length of femur ○ Trunk height is (N) ○ Arm span and Height → Reduced ○ Rhizomelic shortening: Shortening is more in proximal bones ○ Mental and sexual development is (N) ○ Hands are short/broad → central 3 fingers may be of equal length Starfish hand appearance → Trident hand appearance ○ Radiography: Champagne glass appearance scalloping of vertebra / bullet shaped vertebra

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options: A, B & D: This is a case of achondroplasia , an Autosomal dominant condition; 80% of cases are caused by a spontaneous mutation in the fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 (FGFR3), not FGFR 1, 2 or 4.

questions.text: All the following are features of a CTEV shoe that is a modification of a normal shoe except?
questions.correct_answer: B. Presence of a metatarsal bar
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Presence of a metatarsal bar In CTEV shoes there is no metatarsal bar.

Highyeild:

CTEV Shoes: These are modified shoes, used once a child starts walking. The following modifications are made to the shoe Straight inner border to prevent forefoot adduction. Outer shoe raises to prevent foot inversion. No heel to prevent equinus. These shoes are used until the child is 5 years old

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. In CTEV shoes there is a straight inner border to prevent forefoot adduction Option: C. In CTEV shoes there is outer shoe raises to prevent foot inversion Option: D. In CTEV shoes there is no heel to prevent equinus

questions.text: Which among these is not true about CDH in an older child?

options.label: C
options.text: Lower buttock on the affected side

questions.correct_answer: C. Lower buttock on the affected side
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lower buttock on the affected side Higher buttock on the affected side in CDH in an older child.

Highyeild:

DDH CDH Congenital dislocation of hip- DDH - Developmental dysplasia of hip Etiology - proposed factors: Ligamentous laxity of hip capsule (F>M) Prenatal positioning - breech Postnatal posturing Primary acetabular dysplasia More in western countries > Asian Risk factors: Family H/O DDH Breech presentation Female First born white Oligohydramnios / Torticollis / Metatarsus adductus CI/F: Neonate Barlow Test (Most Provocative test): Adduct hips and give a gentle push → it will dislocate hip Ortolani: Abduct + pull Alli's test / Galeazzi sign: Compare the positions of knees Infant: If the hip is not reducible → limited abduction - Most reliable sign of dislocated hip. Shortening (Galeazzi sign) Asymmetry of thigh folds Walking: Toe walk Abductor lurch/Trendelenburg sign +ve due to hip flexion (1 Lordosis)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Telescopy test is positive in CDH in an older child. Option: B. Trendelenburg test positive in CDH in an older child. Option: D. Asymmetrical thigh folds in CDH in an older child. Higher buttock on the affected side. The rest of the statements are true about CDH in older children.

questions.text: Identify the deformity, shown in the given image?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Madelung's deformity In this deformity the lower radius is curved forwards (ventrally), carrying with it the carpus and hand but leaving the lower ulna sticking out as a lump on the back of the wrist, this is suggestive of Madelung’s deformity.

Highyeild:

Madelung's Deformity/Congenital Subluxation of Wrist Madelung's deformity involves wrist and forearm & is characterized by anterior - ulnar bowing of radius and a dorsally prominent ulna (subluxation) with broadening of wrist.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: G un stock deformity: Cubitus varus or bow elbow or gunstock deformity is the result of malunion occurring as a complication of supracondylar fracture of the humerus "Gun-stock Deformity" - Looks like a loading stock of old long barrel guns Option C: Valgus deformity: Cubitus valgus is a medical deformity in which the forearm is angled away from the body to a greater degree than normal when fully extended. Option D: - Carpal fusion is the abnormal fusion of two or more carpal bones when they fail to segment during intrauterine development

questions.text: Club foot is a very common deformity. All are correct about clubfoot deformity except?

options.label: A
options.text: Club foot occurs once in every 1000 births

options.label: B
options.text: Best treatment is correction by non-operative method given by Ponseti

options.label: C
options.text: Sometimes neurological involvement can be present

questions.correct_answer: B. Best treatment is correction by non-operative method given by Ponseti
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Best treatment is correction by non-operative method given by Ponseti The best treatment is correction by operative method given by Ponseti The ponseti method is a nonoperative treatment method – the O.P. casting method Most of the club foot can be corrected by this method nowadays The cast is applied every 5 to 7 days and gradual correction is achieved First cavus, then adduction, varus and lastly equinus is corrected Sometimes remained equinus can be treated by percutaneous tenotomy also

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Club foot occurs once in every 1000 births Club foot occurs once in every 1000 births Club foot is a very common deformity. Option: C. Sometimes neurological involvement can be present Sometimes neurological involvement can be present It is called secondary clubfoot Neurological examination is a necessary part of club foot patient examination Option: D. Tendo-Achilles is short and tight Tendo-Achilles is short and tight Because of tight tendo Achilles equinus deformity present The plantar fascia is also tight.
